A 7‑year‑old boy presented with a 3‑week history of progressive gait instability, diplopia, and morning headaches. MRI of the brain revealed a diffuse, infiltrative lesion centered in the pons, measuring 3.2 cm in greatest dimension, with characteristic T2 hyperintensity and minimal contrast enhancement. An image‑guided stereotactic biopsy was performed. Histopathology confirmed a World Health Organization grade IV diffuse midline glioma. Molecular profiling demonstrated the canonical H3F3A K27M mutation, a concurrent TP53 missense mutation (R175H), and high‑level amplification of PDGFRA (copy number >10). No ACVR1 mutation was detected.

The patient was enrolled in the multicenter phase II trial DRAGON‑001, which investigated concurrent radiation therapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions) with the oral small‑molecule ONC201 (150 mg/m² once daily). After 6 weeks of combined treatment, repeat MRI showed a 30 % reduction in tumor volume, meeting criteria for a partial response. However, at the 4‑month follow‑up, the lesion demonstrated progression with a 25 % increase in volume compared with the nadir.

The DRAGON‑001 trial reported a median progression‑free survival (PFS) of 5.2 months for patients with H3K27M‑mutated DIPG, compared with historical controls of 3.1 months, and grade 2 thrombocytopenia was the most common adverse event (observed in 18 % of participants).

Following progression, the patient entered a compassionate‑use protocol for an H3K27M peptide vaccine (0.5 mg subcutaneously weekly for 12 weeks). The vaccine was well tolerated, and subsequent imaging demonstrated stable disease for an additional 3 months.

Given the PDGFRA amplification, the treating team considered enrollment in an ongoing phase II study of crenolanib, a selective PDGFRA/B tyrosine‑kinase inhibitor administered at 150 mg orally twice daily. Preliminary data from that study indicated a median overall survival of 12.4 months in PDGFRA‑amplified DIPG patients versus 10.3 months in historical controls, representing a 2‑month survival advantage.
